children.text: For the first time in over two years, yesterday I went to an actual,
real-world conference

. It couldn’t quite escape the touch of Zoom: one speaker had to use it to join her panel, due to a dose of COVID-19. But it was great to sit and listen to people talking intelligently about journalism again.
Of course, as with so many conferences, the “lobby con” was one of the best parts. It was great to catch up with people like
Sarah
Greg
Nic
Alistair, and
many others, including a couple of people who might be reading this now… I also got to meet
MoJo mastermind Robb
in person for the first time.
Ironically, I’m fairly sure the last event I attended before the pandemic hit was also in News UK’s building by London Bridge. So, it was nice to be back above London, hearing
Times
editor John Witherow call this a “golden age for serious journalism” to what I think it would be fair to call a mixed reaction.

That’s one thing you miss when a conference is on Zoom. The whispered discussions, the intakes of breath, that distinct feeling of stillness when a speaker has everyone’s attention — and the feel of the room when they disagree with what you’re saying.

It was far from the busiest news:rewired in terms of attendees. I genuinely hope that will change for future iterations — and other conferences in our field. For all the benefits home and hybrid working brings many of us, the chance to gather and discuss things with your peers is invaluable.
Hang on, why didn’t I get yesterday’s posts in my inbox?
Oh, you noticed that, did you?

Rather than spamming your inboxes with half a dozen posts yesterday, I decided to just publish them on the site, and send you an aggregate newsletter today. The links to the liveblogs of the sessions I attended are below.
Let me know if this is a good approach for you.
Things I missed
I do somewhat regret not attending the session on first party data, which Nic was enthusiastic about over lunch. That sounded like an excellent session.

tweets.text:
…Key takeaways on reaching young people:
Go to the platforms where they are
Speak a language they understand
Come from a place of authenticity
Find your own voice
Know the platform & get basics right (no horizontal vids on Tik Tok)
#newsrw

tweets.text: So many good points in session on young people, no time to tweet 😬 #newsrw

children.text: My highlight
This, for me, was the most interesting session of the day, with some real insight into newsletter strategy, and how it's changing:

metadata.title: The future of newsletters
metadata.description: The newsletter boom of the last few years shows no sign of abating. What’s next for this critical auidnce tool, asked a panel at news:rewired.
metadata.author: Adam Tinworth

children.text: The sessions I caught

metadata.title: Zaina Erhaim: how to respect local journalists in crisis zones
metadata.description: The contrast between the coverage of war in Syrai and Ukraine is shocking and stark, argues the news:rewired keynoter. Here’s how we can do better.
metadata.author: Adam Tinworth

metadata.title: Building resilient newsrooms
metadata.description: From grusome images on social media to war reporting and pandemics — journalists are under more stress than ever. How do we help keep our newrooms productive, and our staff healthy?
metadata.author: Adam Tinworth

metadata.title: Platforms and Publishers: the best of frenemies?
metadata.description: Are we any nearer buidling a more healthy relationship between news publishers and social media platforms? The outlook is not good, suggests a news:rewired panel…
metadata.author: Adam Tinworth

metadata.title: Can news tackle polarisation and mend democracy?
metadata.description: Polarisation has been on the rise in many societies for the past decade. Is news stoking the conflict — and can better reporting be part of the solution?
metadata.author: Adam Tinworth

metadata.title: Subscriber revenue: what’s the future — and the limit?
metadata.description: How do you win an audience. convert them to subscribers — and retain them in tough economic times? A news:rewired panel explores past sucesses and future strategies.
metadata.author: Adam Tinworth

metadata.title: Training and retaining the journalists of the future
metadata.description: How do we recruit and retain a more skilled, diverse staff of journalists? The final panel of news:rewired set out to answer that question.
metadata.author: Adam Tinworth

children.text: And finally…
